NYSUT Vice President's office files., 1969-2005
Collection Number: 6174/002

Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation & Archives
Cornell University Library

DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY

Title:
NYSUT Vice President's office files, 1969-2005
Repository:
Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation & Archives
Collection Number:
6174/002
Abstract:
This collection consists of subject files, meeting minutes, reports, and correspondence from the Vice-Presidents' office. The files are arranged alphabetically by subject. These files date mostly from Antonia Cortese's tenure as First Vice-President, though some are earlier.
Creator:
New York State United Teachers
Antonia Cortese
Quanitities:
33 cubic feet
Language:
Collection material in English
Biographical / Historical

New York State United Teachers (NYSUT) was created in 1972 by the merger of the New York State Teachers Association (NYSTA) and the United Teachers of New York (UTNY). NYSTA had been affiliated with the National Education Association (NEA), and UTNY with the American Federation of Teachers (AFT). UTNY was the statewide organization whose United Federation of Teachers (UFT), led by Albert Shanker, was the predominant teachers' union in New York City. In joining with United Teachers and affiliating with the AFT, NYSUT also became a member union of the AFL-CIO.
In 1976, NYSUT voted to disaffiliate with the NEA. Some locals left NYSUT and created the NYEA (New York Educators Association), which became the state affiliate for the NEA. In the early 1980s, NYEA changed its name to NEA-NY.
NYEA/NEA-NY viewed association with the AFL-CIO's industrial unions as undermining the professional image and independence of teachers. The two organizations also differed strongly on aspects of the governance structure, particularly with respect to ethnic minority representation, with NYSUT opposed to mandatory minimums. The rivalry between NYSUT and NYEA/NEA-NY in organizing new locals expended a great deal of resources for both labor organizations.
While competition with NYEA/NEA-NY was a constant focus of NYSUT's organizing efforts for teachers, NYSUT was also organizing college faculty members, nurses, and other non-teaching personnel. Once members were organized, NYSUT continued to advocate for teachers' and other workers' rights through contract support and legal services at the local level and political involvement at the state and federal levels, supporting candidates and legislation that protected funding, due process, and working conditions.
NEA-N Y merged with NYSUT in 2006, by which time NYSUT had grown to more than half a million members, becoming the largest union in New York State.
Biographical / Historical

The Vice President's Office directs NYSUT's initiatives on educational policy and is its frontline advocate to the New York State Board of Regents and the State Education Department.
The Vice President's Office oversees the Division of Research and Educational Services, created in 1974, and the Education and Learning Trust (called the Effective Teaching Program until 2005), NYSUT's professional development arm.
Maria Neira was elected First Vice President in 2005 after serving as Second Vice President for six months; she succeeded Antonia Cortese, who had been First Vice President since 1985 after serving as Second Vice President since 1973. Cortese left NYSUT in 2004 to become executive vice president of the American Federation of Teachers (AFT). Maria Neira also serves as a vice president of the AFT.
In 2007, the titles First Vice President and Second Vice President were changed simply to Vice President, with the duties of each carried over to the officers who held the former respective positions. Maria Neira remains the director of the divisions and programs traditionally under the first vice president's purview, and also coordinates NYSUT's fundraising activities for the American Cancer Society.
Vice President Kathleen Donahue, elected second vice president in 2005, oversees Program Services, which addresses the needs of NYSUT's health care professionals, members of small and rural locals, new members and retirees. It also provides training in workplace health and safety issues.
These records are mostly the files of Antonia Cortese. They consist of memos, correspondence, reports, and background material related to various NYSUT task forces and committees. Also included are minutes and correspondence related to meetings of the AFL-CIO Executive Council (2002-2004), the AFT Executive Council (1987-2005), NYSUT Board of Directors (2001-2005), Executive Committee (2000-2003), Officers (2001-2003), and Policy Council (1998-2004).
Acronyms are generally spelled out, unless the entity is better known by the acronym (e.g., AFL-CIO, AFT, CUNY, NYSUT); task forces and committees are generally listed under the main subject.
Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.
Conditions Governing Use

This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.
INFORMATION FOR USERS
Preferred Citation

NYSUT Vice President's office files. #6174/002. Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library.

Scope and Contents
Joint Statement of Position Presented to the MTA (NYC Metropolitan Transit Authority), May 19, 2004; term sheet (agreement), 4/19/04; minutes of NYS AFL-CIO Executive Council meeting, December 10, 2003; agenda for meeting of June 2, 2004; biographical sketches of union local officers; program for NYS AFL-CIO Annual Labor Celebration, August 9, 2004; poster, "Speaking of Freedomï¿½How about the freedom to have a union and a good contract?" n.d.; NYS AFL-CIO budget projection for the period July 1, 2004. June 30, 2005; budgets for departments; budget analysis for the period July 1, 2003 through March 31, 2004; invitation to breakfast in honor of congressman Charles Rangel, June 14, 2004; agenda for 30th annual Constitutional Convention; flyers, including Call to Action from AFL-CIO president John Sweeney, Voice@Work Campaign 2004 and comparison sheet re John Kerry vs. George Bush on union issues; voter registration materials, targeted to union workers

Task Force on Alternative Education. GED 12/5/01-12/02

School Voucher Program: Preliminary Findings from an Independent Study," prepared by Capital Assessments, Inc., December 1998; revised Proposal of Services to Evaluate the A.B.C. Tuition Assistance Program, submitted by MAGI Educational Services, Inc., with cover letter to NYSUT research director Charles Santelli, December 1997; critical evaluation of initial MAGI proposal; newspaper clippings. See also: Edison

; See also: Education Alternatives

; See also: Low-Performing Schools

Box 16
NYSUT MEETINGS RESTRICTED:
Box 17 Folder 1
NYSUT Board of Directors and Executive Committee . Antonia Cortese Meeting 6/9/04
 2004
Scope and Contents
Agendas; report of the first vice president, for Board of Directors meeting; 2004-05 Allocations for Title I, Parts A and D for New York State School Districts, Charter Schools and Special Act School Districts (No Child Left Behind), preliminary as of June 3, 2004, Sorted Alpha by County, prepared by NYSUT Research and Educational Services; State Education Department discussion item for Regents: summary of Strategy to Implement the Regents Policy Statement on Middle-Level Education, June 16, 2004; memo from Cortese to NYSUT Board of Directors, requesting approval for new NYSUT policy recommendation on Adequate Yearly Progress and students with disabilities, students caught in the performance gap, to be sent to State Education Department, June 28
Box 17 Folder 2
NYSUT Board of Directors Meeting December 12-13, 2003
 2003
Scope and Contents
Agenda; minutes; reports of president (Hobart), first vice president (Cortese), second vice president (Dunn), secretary-treasurer (Tiger; including auditor's report), field and legal services (Kinsella; re bargaining, organizing activities); resolution by Board of Directors authorizing $1 million fund for legal self-insurance; State Education Department Draft Report to the Governor and the Legislature on the Educational Effectiveness of the Charter School Approach, November 7, 2003; report and recommendations of the NYSUT Ad Hoc Task Force on School Finance, November 2003; summary report to NYSUT Executive Committee and Board of Directors, apparently by political/legislative department, re changes to Medicare (prescription drug program), delegate elections to Democratic National Convention, by candidate; overview of impact of new Medicare law on New Yorkers; NYSUT Building Corporation Membership Meeting agenda and audit report

Executive Committee, Rochester 11/15/01
 2001
Scope and Contents

 2002

Box 32 Folder 7

Scope and Contents
